informal_statement:
4. In $\triangle A B C$, the sides opposite to angles $A, B, C$ are denoted as $a, b, c (b \neq 1)$, respectively, and $\frac{C}{A}, \frac{\sin B}{\sin A}$ are both roots of the equation $\log _{\sqrt{6}} x=$ $\log _{b}(4 x-4)$. Then $\triangle A B C$
(A) is an isosceles triangle, but not a right triangle
(B) is a right triangle, but not an isosceles triangle
(C) is an isosceles right triangle
(D) is neither an isosceles triangle nor a right triangle
Answer ( )
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 4. In $\triangle A B C$, the sides opposite to angles $A, B, C$ are denoted as $a, b, c (b \neq 1)$, respectively, and $\frac{C}{A}, \frac{\sin B}{\sin A}$ are both roots of the equation $\log _{\sqrt{6}} x=$ $\log _{b}(4 x-4)$. Then $\triangle A B C$
(A) is an isosceles triangle, but not a right triangle
(B) is a right triangle, but not an isosceles triangle
(C) is an isosceles right triangle
(D) is neither an isosceles triangle nor a right triangle
Answer ( ) -/
theorem algebra_193991 {A B C : Real} (hA : A ∈ Ioo 0 π)
  (hB : B ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hC : C ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hABC : A + B + C = π)
  (h1 : logb (sqrt 6) (C / A) = logb b (4 * C / A - 4)) (h2 : logb (sqrt 6) (sin B / sin A) = logb b (4 * sin B / sin A - 4))
  (hb : b ≠ 1) :
  B = π / 2 ∧ ¬(A = B ∨ B = C ∨ A = C) := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 \sum \frac{a^{2}-b c}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}} \\
& =\sum \frac{(a+b)(a-c)+(a-b)(a+c)}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}} \\
& =\sum\left(\frac{(a+b)(a-c)}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}}+\frac{(c-a)(c+b)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+k c^{2}}\right) \\
& =\sum(a-c)\left(\frac{a+b}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}}-\frac{c+b}{a^{2}+b^{2}+k c^{2}}\right) \\
= & \sum(a-c)^{2} \frac{\sum a^{2}+(1-k) \sum a b}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+k c^{2}\right)} \\
\geqslant & \sum(a-c)^{2} \frac{(2-k)(a b+b c+c a)}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+k c^{2}\right)} \\
\geqslant & 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

This is clearly true.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Given $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}, 0 \leqslant k<2$. Prove:
$$
\sum \frac{a^{2}-b c}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}} \geqslant 0,
$$

where, $\sum$ denotes the cyclic sum.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 Given $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}, 0 \leqslant k<2$. Prove:
$$
\sum \frac{a^{2}-b c}{b^{2}+c^{2}+k a^{2}} \geqslant 0,
$$

where, $\sum$ denotes the cyclic sum. -/
theorem inequalities_317106 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (k : ℝ) (hk : 0 ≤ k ∧ k < 2) :
    (a^2 - b * c) / (b^2 + c^2 + k * a^2) + (b^2 - c * a) / (c^2 + a^2 + k * b^2) +
    (c^2 - a * b) / (a^2 + b^2 + k * c^2) ≥ 0 := by

soln_description:
Proof: (I) Without loss of generality, let $a<0<b$, then $a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant 0 \leqslant b\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$.
Notice that $\left|\cos \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant 1,\left|\sin \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant 1$, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\min (a, b)=a \leqslant a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant y \\
\leqslant b\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant b=\max (a, b) .
\end{array}
$$

When $a_{i}=0(1 \leqslant i \leqslant n)$, $y_{\text {min }}=a$, when $\alpha_{i}=\frac{\pi}{2}(1 \leqslant i \leqslant n)$, $y_{\text {max }}=b$.
(II) When $n=1$, since
$$
\left(a\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right|+b\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right|\right)^{2}+\left(a\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right|-\right.
$$
$\left.b\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right|\right)^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}$, by (I) we know $-b \leqslant$ $a\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right|-b\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right| \leqslant a$. Therefore,
$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & \leqslant\left(a\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right|-b\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right|\right)^{2} \\
& \leqslant \max \left(a^{2}, b^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $a^{2}+b^{2}-\max \left(a^{2}, b^{2}\right) \leqslant y^{2}$
$$
\leqslant a^{2}+b^{2} \text {. }
$$

Since $y \geqslant 0$, we have $\min (a, b) \leqslant y \leqslant \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$.

When $n \geqslant 2$, without loss of generality, assume $a \leqslant b$, applying the conclusion for $n=1$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right|+\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant\left|\cos \alpha_{1} \cos \alpha_{2}\right| \\
\quad+\left|\sin \alpha_{1} \sin \alpha_{2}\right| \\
=\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right| \cdot\left|\cos \alpha_{2}\right|+\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right| \cdot\left|\sin \alpha_{2}\right| \\
\leqslant \sqrt{\left|\cos \alpha_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|\sin \alpha_{1}\right|^{2}}=1,
\end{array}
$$

we have $\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant 1-\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$,
$a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{\pi} \cos \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant a\left(1-\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|\right)$
$\leqslant b\left(1-\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|\right)$.

Rearranging, we get $y=a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right|+b\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right| \leqslant b$.
Clearly, $y \geqslant 0$, so $0 \leqslant y \leqslant b=\max (a, b)$.
Corollary $\left|a \prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}+b \prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$
$\leqslant \max (|a|,|b|)(n \geqslant 2)$.
Proof: $\left|a \prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}+b \prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$
$\leqslant|a| \cdot\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right|+|b| \cdot\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$
$\leqslant \max (|a|,|b|)$.
informal_statement:
Proposition Let $a_{i} \in R(1 \leqslant i \leqslant n), n \in N$, and denote $y=a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right|+b\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$. Then
(I) When $a b0, b>0$, if $n=1$, then $\min (a, b) \leqslant y \leqslant \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$; if $n \geqslant 2$, then $0 \leqslant y$ $\leqslant \max (a, b)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Proposition Let $a_{i} \in R(1 \leqslant i \leqslant n), n \in N$, and denote $y=a\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cos \alpha_{i}\right|+b\left|\prod_{i=1}^{n} \sin \alpha_{i}\right|$. Then
(I) When $a b0, b>0$, if $n=1$, then $\min (a, b) \leqslant y \leqslant \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$; if $n \geqslant 2$, then $0 \leqslant y$ $\leqslant \max (a, b)$. -/
theorem inequalities_309161 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (a b : ℝ)
  (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0) (α : Fin n → ℝ)
  (y : ℝ) (hy : y = a * abs (∏ i : Fin n, cos (α i)) +
    b * abs (∏ i : Fin n, sin (α i))) :
  (n = 1 → min a b ≤ y ∧ y ≤ sqrt (a^2 + b^2)) ∧
  (n ≥ 2 → 0 ≤ y ∧ y ≤ max a b) :=

soln_description:
$$\text { 7. } \begin{aligned}
1= & u \sqrt{v w}+v \sqrt{w u}+w \sqrt{u v}=\sqrt{u v w}(\sqrt{u}+\sqrt{v}+\sqrt{w})= \\
& \sqrt{3 u v w} \sqrt{\frac{(\sqrt{u}+\sqrt{v}+\sqrt{w})^{2}}{3}} \leqslant \\
& \sqrt{3\left(\frac{u+v+w}{3}\right)^{3}} \sqrt{u+v+w}= \\
& \frac{1}{3}(u+v+w)^{2}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the minimum value of $u+v+w$ is $\sqrt{3}$.
informal_statement: 7. Let $u, v, w$ be positive real numbers, satisfying the condition $u \sqrt{v w}+v \sqrt{w u}+w \sqrt{u v}=1$. Find the minimum value of $u+v+w$. (3rd China Girls Mathematical Olympiad Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- 7. Let $u, v, w$ be positive real numbers, satisfying the condition $u \sqrt{v w}+v \sqrt{w u}+w \sqrt{u v}=1$. Find the minimum value of $u+v+w$. (3rd China Girls Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem algebra_602318 (u v w : ℝ) (hu : 0 < u) (hv : 0 < v) (hw : 0 < w)
    (h : u * sqrt (v * w) + v * sqrt (w * u) + w * sqrt (u * v) = 1) :
    u + v + w ≥ sqrt 3 ∧
    ∃ u v w : ℝ, 0 < u ∧ 0 < v ∧ 0 < w ∧
      u * sqrt (v * w) + v * sqrt (w * u) + w * sqrt (u * v) = 1 ∧
      u + v + w = sqrt 3 := by

soln_description:
16. The answer is (B).

Let $x$ be the number of Andrea's classmates. The amount he expects to spend is $13 x$ cents, while the amount he actually spends is $10 x$ cents. The difference between these amounts is exactly the cost of 6 candies, which is 60 cents. Consequently, $x$ can be determined by solving the equation $13 x - 10 x = 60$, or $3 x = 60$, from which $x = 20$. The correct answer is $\mathbf{B}$.
informal_statement:
16) Andrea enters a store with the exact amount of money to buy a candy for each of her classmates, at a price of thirteen cents each. However, the price of the candies has dropped to ten cents each, and Andrea buys six more candies than planned, using up all the money she had. How many classmates does Andrea have?
(A) 18,
(B) 20,
(C) 21,
(D) 23
(E) 24
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 16) Andrea enters a store with the exact amount of money to buy a candy for each of her classmates, at a price of thirteen cents each. However, the price of the candies has dropped to ten cents each, and Andrea buys six more candies than planned, using up all the money she had. How many classmates does Andrea have?
(A) 18,
(B) 20,
(C) 21,
(D) 23
(E) 24 -/
theorem algebra_128843 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) :
    n * 13 = (n + 6) * 10 := by

informal_statement: Given the function $f(x) = \frac{2x-1}{3x+5}$, determine the formula for its inverse function $f^{-1}(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Given the function $f(x) = \frac{2x-1}{3x+5}$, determine the formula for its inverse function $f^{-1}(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_3694 {f g : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : f = fun x => (2 * x - 1) / (3 * x + 5)) (hg : g = fun x => (5 * x + 1) / (2 - 3 * x)) : f = g⁻¹ := by

soln_description:
1. **Understanding the Condition:**
   The given condition is \(i + j \mid ia_i + ja_j\) for all \(i, j \in \{1, 2, \ldots, 2016\}\). This can be rewritten as:
   \[
   i + j \mid i(a_i - a_j)
   \]
   This implies that \(i + j\) must divide \(i(a_i - a_j)\).

2. **Analyzing the Divisibility:**
   Since \(i + j\) divides \(i(a_i - a_j)\), we need to consider the greatest common divisor (gcd) of \(i\) and \(i + j\). Notice that:
   \[
   \gcd(i, i + j) = \gcd(i, j)
   \]
   If \(i\) and \(j\) are coprime (i.e., \(\gcd(i, j) = 1\)), then \(i + j\) must divide \(a_i - a_j\).

3. **Special Case for \(2k - 1\):**
   Consider \(i = k\) and \(j = k - 1\). Then:
   \[
   i + j = k + (k - 1) = 2k - 1
   \]
   Since \(\gcd(k, k - 1) = 1\), it follows that:
   \[
   2k - 1 \mid a_k - a_{k-1}
   \]
   If \(2k - 1 > 2016\), then \(a_k = a_{k-1}\) because \(0 \leq a_k, a_{k-1} \leq 2016\).

4. **Implication for Large \(k\):**
   For \(k > 1008\), \(2k - 1 > 2016\). Therefore, \(a_k = a_{k-1}\) for all \(k > 1008\). This implies:
   \[
   a_{1009} = a_{1010} = \ldots = a_{2016}
   \]

5. **Considering Smaller \(i\):**
   For \(i < 1009\), we need to find some \(j\) such that \(\gcd(i, j) = 1\) and \(i + j > 2016\). One such \(j\) can be chosen from \(\{2017 - i, 2017 - i + 1, \ldots, 2016\}\). For these \(j\), we have:
   \[
   i + j \mid a_i - a_j
   \]
   Since \(i + j > 2016\), it follows that \(a_i = a_j = a_{2016}\).

6. **Conclusion:**
   Since \(a_i = a_{2016}\) for all \(i\), all sequences satisfying the given condition must be constant sequences.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ a_1 = a_2 = \ldots = a_{2016} } \).
informal_statement: Determine all sequences of non-negative integers $a_1, \ldots, a_{2016}$ all less than or equal to $2016$ satisfying $i+j\mid ia_i+ja_j$ for all $i, j\in \{ 1,2,\ldots, 2016\}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all sequences of non-negative integers $a_1, \ldots, a_{2016}$ all less than or equal to $2016$ satisfying $i+j\mid ia_i+ja_j$ for all $i, j\in \{ 1,2,\ldots, 2016\}$. -/
theorem number_theory_47965 (a : ℕ → ℕ) (ha : ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2016, a i ≤ 2016)
    (h : ∀ i j : ℕ, i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2016 → j ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2016 → i + j ∣ i * a i + j * a j) :
    ∃ c, ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2016, a i = c := by

informal_statement: A triangle is formed with one vertex at the vertex of the parabola $y=x^2-1$ and the other two vertices at the intersections of the line $y=r$ and the parabola. If the area of the triangle is between $8$ and $64$ inclusive, find all possible values of $r$. Express your answer in interval notation.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A triangle is formed with one vertex at the vertex of the parabola $y=x^2-1$ and the other two vertices at the intersections of the line $y=r$ and the parabola. If the area of the triangle is between $8$ and $64$ inclusive, find all possible values of $r$. Express your answer in interval notation. -/
theorem algebra_14678 (r : ℝ) (h : r ≥ 0) (h1 : 8 ≤ (1 / 2) * (r ^ 2 - 1) * (2 * r - 1)) (h2 : (1 / 2) * (r ^ 2 - 1) * (2 * r - 1) ≤ 64) :
    3 ≤ r ∧ r ≤ 15 := by

soln_description:
To show that \( P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_n} - 1}{3} \) where \( F_n \) is the Fibonacci sequence, we will use mathematical induction.

1. **Base Case:**
   - For \( n = 0 \):
     \[
     P_0(X) = 0
     \]
     We need to check if \( \frac{(3X+7)^{F_0} - 1}{3} = 0 \):
     \[
     F_0 = 0 \implies \frac{(3X+7)^0 - 1}{3} = \frac{1 - 1}{3} = 0
     \]
     This matches \( P_0(X) \).

   - For \( n = 1 \):
     \[
     P_1(X) = X + 2
     \]
     We need to check if \( \frac{(3X+7)^{F_1} - 1}{3} = X + 2 \):
     \[
     F_1 = 1 \implies \frac{(3X+7)^1 - 1}{3} = \frac{3X + 7 - 1}{3} = \frac{3X + 6}{3} = X + 2
     \]
     This matches \( P_1(X) \).

2. **Inductive Step:**
   Assume that the formula holds for \( P_{n-1}(X) \) and \( P_{n-2}(X) \):
   \[
   P_{n-1}(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1}{3}
   \]
   \[
   P_{n-2}(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - 1}{3}
   \]

   We need to show that:
   \[
   P_n(X) = P_{n-1}(X) + 3P_{n-1}(X) \cdot P_{n-2}(X) + P_{n-2}(X)
   \]
   matches:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_n} - 1}{3}
   \]

   Substitute the inductive hypotheses into the recurrence relation:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1}{3} + 3 \left( \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1}{3} \right) \left( \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - 1}{3} \right) + \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - 1}{3}
   \]

   Simplify the expression:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1}{3} + \left( (3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1 \right) \left( \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - 1}{3} \right) + \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - 1}{3}
   \]

   Combine the terms:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - 1 + (3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} (3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} - (3X+7)^{F_{n-1}} - (3X+7)^{F_{n-2}} + 1}{3}
   \]

   Simplify further:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{n-1} + F_{n-2}} - 1}{3}
   \]

   Since \( F_n = F_{n-1} + F_{n-2} \), we have:
   \[
   P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_n} - 1}{3}
   \]

   This completes the inductive step.

Thus, by mathematical induction, we have shown that \( P_n(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_n} - 1}{3} \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

Now, we need to show that if \( k \) divides \( m \), then \( P_k(X) \) divides \( P_m(X) \).

3. **Divisibility:**
   - If \( k \) divides \( m \), then \( m = qk \) for some integer \( q \).
   - We know that \( F_m = F_{qk} \).
   - By the properties of the Fibonacci sequence, \( F_k \) divides \( F_{qk} \).

   Therefore:
   \[
   P_m(X) = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_m} - 1}{3} = \frac{(3X+7)^{F_{qk}} - 1}{3}
   \]
   Since \( F_k \) divides \( F_{qk} \), we can write:
   \[
   (3X+7)^{F_{qk}} - 1 = \left( (3X+7)^{F_k} \right)^q - 1
   \]
   This implies that \( (3X+7)^{F_k} - 1 \) divides \( (3X+7)^{F_{qk}} - 1 \).

   Hence, \( P_k(X) \) divides \( P_m(X) \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Polynomials $(P_n(X))_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ are defined as: $$P_0(X)=0, \quad P_1(X)=X+2,$$ $$P_n(X)=P_{n-1}(X)+3P_{n-1}(X)\cdot P_{n-2}(X)+P_{n-2}(X), \quad (\forall) n\geq2.$$ Show that if $ k $ divides $m$ then $P_k(X)$ divides $P_m(X).$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- Polynomials $(P_n(X))_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ are defined as: $$P_0(X)=0, \quad P_1(X)=X+2,$$ $$P_n(X)=P_{n-1}(X)+3P_{n-1}(X)\cdot P_{n-2}(X)+P_{n-2}(X), \quad (\forall) n\geq2.$$ Show that if $ k $ divides $m$ then $P_k(X)$ divides $P_m(X).$  -/
theorem number_theory_37288 {P : ℕ → Polynomial ℤ} (hP0 : P 0 = 0)
    (hP1 : P 1 = X + 2) (hP : ∀ n ≥ 2, P n = P (n - 1) + 3 * P (n - 1) * P (n - 2) + P (n - 2))
    (k m : ℕ) (hm : k ∣ m) : P k ∣ P m := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $a=-\frac{1}{2}$, using the Remainder Theorem we get $r_{1}=a^{8}$. From the equation
$$
x^{8}=(x-a) q_{1}(x)+r_{1}=(x-a) q_{1}(x)+a^{8} \text {, }
$$

we have
$$
q_{1}(x)=\frac{x^{8}-a^{8}}{x-a}=x^{7}+a x^{6}+\cdots+a^{7} \text {, }
$$

or
$$
q_{1}(x)=\left(x^{4}+a^{4}\right)\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)(x+a) .
$$

Therefore, when $q_{1}(x)$ is divided by $x-a$, using the Remainder Theorem we have
$$
r_{2}=q_{1}(a)=8 a^{7}=-\frac{1}{16} \text {. }
$$

Thus, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
$29 \cdot 62$ When the polynomial $x^{8}$ is divided by $x+\frac{1}{2}$, let $q_{1}(x)$ and $r_{1}$ represent the quotient and remainder, respectively. When $q_{1}(x)$ is again divided by $x+\frac{1}{2}$, let $q_{2}(x)$ and $r_{2}$ represent the quotient and remainder, respectively. Then $r_{2}$ equals
(A) $\frac{1}{256}$.
(B) $-\frac{1}{16}$.
(C) 1 .
(D) -16 .
(E) 256 .
(30th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1979)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $29 \cdot 62$ When the polynomial $x^{8}$ is divided by $x+\frac{1}{2}$, let $q_{1}(x)$ and $r_{1}$ represent the quotient and remainder, respectively. When $q_{1}(x)$ is again divided by $x+\frac{1}{2}$, let $q_{2}(x)$ and $r_{2}$ represent the quotient and remainder, respectively. Then $r_{2}$ equals
(A) $\frac{1}{256}$.
(B) $-\frac{1}{16}$.
(C) 1 .
(D) -16 .
(E) 256 .
(30th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1979) -/
theorem algebra_218220 {f : Polynomial ℝ} (hf : f = X^8) :
    (f / (X + 1 / 2)) % (X + 1 / 2) = -1 / 16 := by

soln_description: Answer: $2 R / \mu=4155$ J $/($ kg $K)$.
informal_statement:
5. Let's define the equation of the process. Since the piston is light, the spring's elastic force at any moment is equal to the gas pressure force:

$$
k x=p(x) S
$$

where $x$ is the length of the cylinder occupied by the gas, which by condition is equal to the compression of the spring, $k$ is the spring stiffness coefficient, and $S$ is the base area of the cylinder. Multiplying both sides of the equation by $S$, we get

$$
p=\alpha V, \quad \alpha=\text { const. }
$$

Let's find the heat capacity of the gas in this process:

$$
c=\frac{d Q}{d T}
$$

Suppose the volume of the gas $V$ changes by a small amount $d V$. Then the pressure changes from $p$ to $d p=\alpha d V$, and the internal energy changes by

$$
d U=\frac{3}{2}((p+d p)(V+d V)-p V)=\frac{3}{2}(p d V+V d p)=3 \alpha V d V
$$

The temperature change will be $d T=\frac{2}{3} \frac{d U}{\nu R}=\frac{2 \alpha V d V}{\nu R}$.

The work done by the gas is $d A=p d V=\alpha V d V$.

The heat supplied to the system is

$$
d Q=d U+d A=4 \alpha V d V
$$

and the heat capacity is

$$
c=\frac{d Q}{d T}=2 \nu R
$$

To find the specific heat capacity, we need to divide the heat capacity of the entire gas by its mass $\nu \mu$, where $\mu$ is the molar mass of the gas.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Let's define the equation of the process. Since the piston is light, the spring's elastic force at any moment is equal to the gas pressure force:

$$
k x=p(x) S
$$

where $x$ is the length of the cylinder occupied by the gas, which by condition is equal to the compression of the spring, $k$ is the spring stiffness coefficient, and $S$ is the base area of the cylinder. Multiplying both sides of the equation by $S$, we get

$$
p=\alpha V, \quad \alpha=\text { const. }
$$

Let's find the heat capacity of the gas in this process:

$$
c=\frac{d Q}{d T}
$$

Suppose the volume of the gas $V$ changes by a small amount $d V$. Then the pressure changes from $p$ to $d p=\alpha d V$, and the internal energy changes by

$$
d U=\frac{3}{2}((p+d p)(V+d V)-p V)=\frac{3}{2}(p d V+V d p)=3 \alpha V d V
$$

The temperature change will be $d T=\frac{2}{3} \frac{d U}{\nu R}=\frac{2 \alpha V d V}{\nu R}$.

The work done by the gas is $d A=p d V=\alpha V d V$.

The heat supplied to the system is

$$
d Q=d U+d A=4 \alpha V d V
$$

and the heat capacity is

$$
c=\frac{d Q}{d T}=2 \nu R
$$

To find the specific heat capacity, we need to divide the heat capacity of the entire gas by its mass $\nu \mu$, where $\mu$ is the molar mass of the gas. -/
theorem algebra_276942 {p : ℝ → ℝ} (hp : p = fun x => k * x / S) (k : ℝ) (S : ℝ)
    (h : k > 0) (hS : S > 0) (α : ℝ) (hα : α > 0) (V : ℝ) (hV : V > 0)
    (dV : ℝ) (hdV : dV > 0) (hU : U = 3 / 2 * ((p V + α * dV) * (V + dV) - p V * V))
    (hA : A = α * V * dV) (hQ : Q = U + A) (hT : T = 2 / 3 * (Q / (α * V * dV))) :
    c = 2 * R / μ := by

informal_statement: Given real numbers $x$, $y$, $z$ satisfy $x+y=2$, $\left| z+3 \right|=xy-6y-4$, then $x+2y+3z=$ ___        ___ .
informal_proof:
We are given two equations involving real numbers $x, y, z$:
1. $x + y = 2$
2. $|z + 3| = xy - 6y - 4$

Our goal is to find the value of the expression $x + 2y + 3z$.

First, from equation (1), we can express $x$ in terms of $y$:
$x = 2 - y$.

Next, we substitute this expression for $x$ into equation (2):
$|z + 3| = (2 - y)y - 6y - 4$

Let's simplify the right-hand side of this new equation:
$|z + 3| = 2y - y^2 - 6y - 4$
$|z + 3| = -y^2 - 4y - 4$
$|z + 3| = -(y^2 + 4y + 4)$
$|z + 3| = -(y + 2)^2$

Now we have the crucial equation: $|z + 3| = -(y + 2)^2$.
By the definition of the absolute value, the left-hand side, $|z + 3|$, must be non-negative. For any real number $y$, the term $(y + 2)^2$ is also non-negative. Therefore, the right-hand side, $-(y + 2)^2$, must be non-positive.

The only way a non-negative number can be equal to a non-positive number is if both are equal to zero. Thus, we must have:
- $|z + 3| = 0$
- $-(y + 2)^2 = 0$

From $|z + 3| = 0$, we conclude that $z + 3 = 0$, which gives us $z = -3$.

From $-(y + 2)^2 = 0$, we conclude that $(y + 2)^2 = 0$, which implies $y + 2 = 0$, giving us $y = -2$.

Now that we have the value of $y$, we can find $x$ using our initial substitution:
$x = 2 - y = 2 - (-2) = 4$.

So, we have uniquely determined the values: $x = 4$, $y = -2$, and $z = -3$.

Finally, we substitute these values into the target expression:
$x + 2y + 3z = 4 + 2(-2) + 3(-3)$
$= 4 - 4 - 9$
$= -9$

Thus, we have shown that $x + 2y + 3z = -9$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given real numbers $x$, $y$, $z$ satisfy $x+y=2$, $\left| z+3 \right|=xy-6y-4$, then $x+2y+3z=$ ___        ___ . -/
theorem algebra_3565 {x y z : ℝ} (h1 : x + y = 2) (h2 : |z + 3| = x * y - 6 * y - 4) :
    x + 2 * y + 3 * z = -9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_3565 {x y z : ℝ} (h1 : x + y = 2) (h2 : |z + 3| = x * y - 6 * y - 4) :
    x + 2 * y + 3 * z = -9 := by
  have hx : x = 2 - y := by linarith
  rw [hx] at h2
  have h5 : (z + 3) ^ 2 = 0 := by
    cases abs_cases (z + 3) with
    | inl hz =>
      have : (z + 3) ^ 2 = 0 := by 
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
      assumption
    | inr hz =>
      have : (z + 3) ^ 2 = 0 := by 
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
      assumption
  have h6 : z + 3 = 0 := by 
    rw [sq_eq_zero_iff] at h5
    exact h5
  have h7 : z = -3 := by linarith
  have h8 : y + 2 = 0 := by
    cases abs_cases (z + 3) with
    | inl hz =>
      have : y + 2 = 0 := by 
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
      assumption
    | inr hz =>
      have : y + 2 = 0 := by 
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
      assumption
  have h9 : y = -2 := by linarith
  have h10 : x = 4 := by 
    linarith
  linarith [h7, h9, h10]

soln_description:
Solution: Multiply by 4 to complete the square, getting $(2 x+1)^{2}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=4\left(y^{4}+y^{3}+y^{2}+y\right)+1 \\
=\left(2 y^{2}+y+1\right)^{2}-y^{2}+2 y \\
=\left(2 y^{2}+y\right)^{2}+3 y^{2}+4 y+1 .
\end{array}
$$
$\therefore$ When $y>2$ or $y<-1$, $\left(2 y^{2}+y\right)^{2}<(2 x+1)^{2}<\left(2 y^{2}+y+1\right)^{2}$,
$\therefore-1 \leqslant y \leqslant 2, y=-1,0,1,2$, the solutions to the equation are $(x, y)=(0,-1),(-1,-1),(0,0),(-1,0),(-6,2),(5,2)$.
informal_statement:
Example 3 Find the integer solutions of $x^{2}+x=y^{4}+y^{3}+y^{2}+y$.

Translate the above text into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3 Find the integer solutions of $x^{2}+x=y^{4}+y^{3}+y^{2}+y$.

Translate the above text into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_241040 :
    {(x, y) : ℤ × ℤ | x^2 + x = y^4 + y^3 + y^2 + y} =
    {(0, -1), (-1, -1), (0, 0), (-1, 0), (-6, 2), (5, 2)} := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{0}^{2}-2 b_{0}^{2}=-1, \\
a_{1}^{2}-2 b_{1}^{2}=1, \\
\ldots \ldots
\end{array}
$$

Conjecture $a_{n}^{2}-2 b_{n}^{2}=(-1)^{n+1}(n=0,1 \ldots)$.
We will prove this by mathematical induction.
Assume the proposition holds for $n=k$, that is,
$$
a_{k}^{2}-2 b_{k}^{2}=(-1)^{k+1} \text {. }
$$

Then for $n=k+1$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{k+1}^{2}-2 b_{k+1}^{2}=\left(a_{k}+2 b_{k}\right)^{2}-2\left(a_{k}+b_{k}\right)^{2} \\
=-\left(a_{k}^{2}-2 b_{k}^{2}\right)=(-1)^{k+2} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, by mathematical induction, the conjecture is true.
Thus, $a_{2001}^{2}-2 b_{2001}^{2}=1$.
informal_statement: Four. (20 points) The sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy $a_{0}=$ $b_{0}=1, a_{n}=a_{n-1}+2 b_{n-1}, b_{n}=a_{n-1}+b_{n-1}$, $(n=1,2 \ldots)$. Find the value of $a_{2001}^{2}-2 b_{2001}^{2}$.
informal_proof:
Let the sequences of integers $\{a_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ and $\{b_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ be defined by the initial conditions $a_0 = 1$, $b_0 = 1$, and the recurrence relations $a_{n+1} = a_n + 2b_n$ and $b_{n+1} = a_n + b_n$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. We want to find the value of $a_{2001}^2 - 2b_{2001}^2$.

To solve this, we will first prove a general formula for $a_n^2 - 2b_n^2$ for any natural number $n$ by mathematical induction. Let $P(n)$ be the proposition $a_n^2 - 2b_n^2 = (-1)^{n+1}$.

**Base Case:** For $n=0$, we must show that $a_0^2 - 2b_0^2 = (-1)^{0+1}$.
Using the given initial values $a_0 = 1$ and $b_0 = 1$, the left-hand side is:
$a_0^2 - 2b_0^2 = 1^2 - 2 \cdot 1^2 = 1 - 2 = -1$.
The right-hand side is $(-1)^{1} = -1$.
Since both sides are equal, the proposition $P(0)$ holds.

**Inductive Step:** Assume that $P(n)$ holds for some natural number $n$. This is our induction hypothesis:
$a_n^2 - 2b_n^2 = (-1)^{n+1}$.
We will now prove that $P(n+1)$ holds, i.e., $a_{n+1}^2 - 2b_{n+1}^2 = (-1)^{(n+1)+1}$.

We start with the left-hand side of the expression for $n+1$ and use the given recurrence relations:
\begin{align*} a_{n+1}^2 - 2b_{n+1}^2 &= (a_n + 2b_n)^2 - 2(a_n + b_n)^2 \\ &= (a_n^2 + 4a_nb_n + 4b_n^2) - 2(a_n^2 + 2a_nb_n + b_n^2) \\ &= a_n^2 + 4a_nb_n + 4b_n^2 - 2a_n^2 - 4a_nb_n - 2b_n^2 \\ &= (a_n^2 - 2a_n^2) + (4a_nb_n - 4a_nb_n) + (4b_n^2 - 2b_n^2) \\ &= -a_n^2 + 2b_n^2 \\ &= -(a_n^2 - 2b_n^2) \end{align*}
By the induction hypothesis, we know that $a_n^2 - 2b_n^2 = (-1)^{n+1}$. Substituting this into our result, we get:
\begin{align*} a_{n+1}^2 - 2b_{n+1}^2 &= -((-1)^{n+1}) \\ &= (-1)^1 \cdot (-1)^{n+1} \\ &= (-1)^{n+2} \\ &= (-1)^{(n+1)+1} \end{align*}
This is precisely the statement $P(n+1)$. Thus, the inductive step is complete.

By the principle of mathematical induction, the formula $a_n^2 - 2b_n^2 = (-1)^{n+1}$ is true for all natural numbers $n$.

Now, we can find the value of the desired expression by setting $n = 2001$:
$a_{2001}^2 - 2b_{2001}^2 = (-1)^{2001+1} = (-1)^{2002}$.
Since 2002 is an even integer, $(-1)^{2002} = 1$.

Therefore, we conclude that $a_{2001}^2 - 2b_{2001}^2 = 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four. (20 points) The sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy $a_{0}=$ $b_{0}=1, a_{n}=a_{n-1}+2 b_{n-1}, b_{n}=a_{n-1}+b_{n-1}$, $(n=1,2 \ldots)$. Find the value of $a_{2001}^{2}-2 b_{2001}^{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_301670 {a b : ℕ → ℤ} (ha0 : a 0 = 1) (hb0 : b 0 = 1)
    (han : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = a n + 2 * b n) (hbn : ∀ n, b (n + 1) = a n + b n) :
    a 2001 ^ 2 - 2 * b 2001 ^ 2 = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_301670 {a b : ℕ → ℤ} (ha0 : a 0 = 1) (hb0 : b 0 = 1)
    (han : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = a n + 2 * b n) (hbn : ∀ n, b (n + 1) = a n + b n) :
    a 2001 ^ 2 - 2 * b 2001 ^ 2 = 1 := by
  have h : ∀ n, a n ^ 2 - 2 * b n ^ 2 = (-1 : ℤ) ^ (n + 1) := by 
    intro n
    induction n with 
    | zero =>
      rw [ha0, hb0]
      norm_num
    | succ n ih =>
      have ha1 : a (n + 1) = a n + 2 * b n := by 
        apply han
      have hb1 : b (n + 1) = a n + b n := by 
        apply hbn
      calc
        a (n + 1) ^ 2 - 2 * b (n + 1) ^ 2 
            = (a n + 2 * b n) ^ 2 - 2 * (a n + b n) ^ 2 := by rw [ha1, hb1]
        _ = (a n ^ 2 + 4 * a n * b n + 4 * b n ^ 2) - 2 * (a n ^ 2 + 2 * a n * b n + b n ^ 2) := by
          ring
        _ = - (a n ^ 2 - 2 * b n ^ 2) := by 
          ring_nf
        _ = - ((-1 : ℤ) ^ (n + 1)) := by rw [ih]
        _ = (-1 : ℤ) ^ ((n + 1) + 1) := by 
          ring_nf
  have h2001 := h 2001
  rw [h2001]
  norm_num

soln_description:
Solution. The given surface (a paraboloid of revolution) is projected one-to-one onto the plane $x O y$ as a circle $D_{x y}$ (Fig. 19). We find the unit normal $\boldsymbol{n}^{0}$ to the surface $S$:

$$
n^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\operatorname{grad}\left(z-x^{2}-y^{2}\right)}{\left|\operatorname{grad}\left(z-x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\right|}= \pm \frac{-2 x \mathbf{i}-2 y \mathbf{j}+\mathbf{k}}{\sqrt{4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+1}}
$$

According to the problem, the normal $\mathbf{n}^{0}$ forms an obtuse angle $\gamma$ with the $O z$ axis, so we should take the negative sign in the fraction. Thus,

$$
n^{0}=\frac{2 x \mathbf{i}+2 y \mathbf{j}-\mathbf{k}}{\sqrt{4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+1}}
$$

Fig. 19

From this,

$$
\cos \gamma=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+1}}<0
$$

and, therefore,

$$
d S=\frac{d x d y}{|\cos \gamma|}=\sqrt{4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+1} d x d y
$$

We find the scalar product

$$
\left(a, n^{0}\right)=\frac{2 y^{3}-z}{\sqrt{4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+1}}
$$

The sought flux, by formula (I), is

$$
\mathrm{n}=\iint_{S}\left(2, \mathrm{n}^{0}\right) d S=\left.\iint_{D_{x y}}\left(2 y^{3}-z\right)\right|_{z=x^{2}+y^{2}} d x d y=\iint_{D_{x y}}\left(2 y^{3}-y^{2}-x^{2}\right) d x d y
$$

The integration region $D_{x y}$ is a circle centered at the origin with radius $\boldsymbol{R}=\sqrt{2}$. Introducing polar coordinates $\boldsymbol{x}=\rho \cos \varphi, y=\rho \sin \varphi$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{II}=\iint_{D_{x y}}\left(2 \rho^{3} \sin ^{3} \varphi-\rho^{2}\right) \rho d \rho d \varphi= \\
&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{\sqrt{2}}\left(2 \rho^{4} \sin ^{3} \varphi-\rho^{3}\right) d \rho=-\left.2 \pi \frac{\rho^{4}}{4}\right|_{0} ^{\sqrt{2}}=-2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
Example 5. Find the flux of the vector field $\mathbf{a} = \boldsymbol{y}^{2} \mathbf{j} + z \mathbf{k}$ through the part of the surface $z = x^{2} + y^{2}$, cut off by the plane $z = 2$. The normal is taken outward with respect to the region bounded by the paraboloid.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_267d965536514099194eg-24.jpg?height=285&width=248&top_left_y=171&top_left_x=106)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 5. Find the flux of the vector field $\mathbf{a} = \boldsymbol{y}^{2} \mathbf{j} + z \mathbf{k}$ through the part of the surface $z = x^{2} + y^{2}$, cut off by the plane $z = 2$. The normal is taken outward with respect to the region bounded by the paraboloid.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_267d965536514099194eg-24.jpg?height=285&width=248&top_left_y=171&top_left_x=106) -/
theorem calculus_152288 (f : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : f = λ x y => x^2 + y^2) :
  ∫ x in (-2)..2, ∫ y in (f x y)..2, (y^2 * j + (f x y) * k) = -2 * π := by

informal_statement: The sum of Jim's weight and Bob's weight is 180 pounds. If you subtract Jim's weight from Bob's weight, you get half of Bob's weight. How many pounds does Bob weigh?
informal_proof:
Let `jim` and `bob` be integers representing their respective weights. We are given the following two equations:
1. `jim + bob = 180`
2. `bob - jim = bob / 2`, where `/` denotes integer division.

Our goal is to prove that `bob = 120`.

First, we observe from the second equation that `bob - jim` is an integer. This implies that `bob / 2` must also be an integer, which means that `bob` must be an even number. Thus, `bob` is divisible by 2.

Since `bob` is even, the integer division `bob / 2` is equivalent to `bob * (1/2)`. We can therefore multiply both sides of the second equation by 2 to eliminate the division, yielding:
`2 * (bob - jim) = bob`

By applying the distributive property to the left side, we get:
`2 * bob - 2 * jim = bob`

Subtracting `bob` from both sides gives:
`bob - 2 * jim = 0`

Adding `2 * jim` to both sides isolates `bob`, showing that Bob's weight is twice Jim's weight:
`bob = 2 * jim`

Now, we substitute this expression for `bob` into the first equation, `jim + bob = 180`:
`jim + (2 * jim) = 180`

This simplifies to:
`3 * jim = 180`

Dividing by 3, we find Jim's weight:
`jim = 60`

Finally, we use this value for `jim` in the equation `bob = 2 * jim` to find Bob's weight:
`bob = 2 * 60`
`bob = 120`

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The sum of Jim's weight and Bob's weight is 180 pounds. If you subtract Jim's weight from Bob's weight, you get half of Bob's weight. How many pounds does Bob weigh? -/
theorem algebra_15587 (jim bob : ℤ) (h₀ : jim + bob = 180) (h₁ : bob - jim = bob / 2) :
    bob = 120 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_15587 (jim bob : ℤ) (h₀ : jim + bob = 180) (h₁ : bob - jim = bob / 2) :
    bob = 120 := by
  have h2 : bob % 2 = 0 := by
    omega
  have h3 : 2 * (bob - jim) = bob := by
    omega
  have h4 : bob = 2 * jim := by 
    linarith 
    all_goals omega
  have hj : jim = 60 := by 
    linarith [h₀, h4]
  linarith [h4, hj]

soln_description:
Prove: According to the AM-GM inequality, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k}=1 \cdot\left(\frac{a_{1}}{1}\right)+2 \cdot\left(\frac{a_{2}}{2}\right)+\cdots+k \cdot\left(\frac{a_{k}}{k}\right) \\
\geq \frac{k(k+1)}{2}\left(\frac{a_{1}}{1}\right)^{\frac{2}{k(k+1)}} \cdot\left(\frac{a_{2}}{2}\right)^{\frac{4}{k(k+1)}} \cdots\left(\frac{a_{k}}{k}\right)^{\frac{2 k}{k(k+1)}}
\end{array}$$

Multiplying the above inequality for \( k \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\} \), we have
$$\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k}\right) \geq \prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\frac{k(k+1)}{2} \prod_{i=1}^{k}\left(\frac{a_{i}}{i}\right)^{\frac{2 i}{k(k+1)}}\right)=\frac{n!(n+1)!}{2^{n}} \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{a_{i}}{i}\right)^{c_{i}}$$

The exponent \( c_{i} \) is determined by the following formula:
$$c_{i}=2 i\left[\frac{1}{i(i+1)}+\frac{1}{(i+1)(i+2)}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n(n+1)}\right]=2 i\left(\frac{1}{i}-\frac{1}{n+1}\right) \leq 2$$

This is because \( a_{i} \leq i \quad i \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\},\left(\frac{a_{i}}{i}\right)^{c_{i}} \geq\left(\frac{a_{i}}{i}\right)^{2} \). Therefore,
$$a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \geq \frac{n!(n+1)!}{2^{n}} \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{a_{i}}{i}\right)^{2}=\frac{n+1}{2^{n}} a_{1}^{2} a_{2}^{2} \cdots a_{n}^{2}$$

Equality holds if and only if \( a_{i}=i(i=1,2, \cdots, n) \).
informal_statement:
Example 1.1.6 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $a_{i} \in[0, i] i \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}$, prove:
$2^{n} a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \geq(n+1) a_{1}^{2} a_{2}^{2} \cdots a_{n}^{2}$
【Phan Thanh Nam】
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 1.1.6 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $a_{i} \in[0, i] i \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}$, prove:
$2^{n} a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \geq(n+1) a_{1}^{2} a_{2}^{2} \cdots a_{n}^{2}$
【Phan Thanh Nam】 -/
theorem inequalities_599719 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 < a i) (h : ∀ i, a i ≤ (i + 1)) :
    2 ^ n * ∏ i, (∑ j in Finset.univ.filter (· ≤ i), a j) ≥
    (n + 1) * ∏ i, (a i) ^ 2 := by

soln_description: 2. A. Reason: From $x^{2}-2 x-3>0$ we have $x3$, thus the domain of the function $\log _{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x^{2}-2 x-3\right)$ is $x3$. The quadratic function $u=x^{2}-2 x-3$ is monotonically decreasing in $(-\infty,-1)$ and monotonically increasing in $(3,+\infty)$, while $\log \frac{1}{2} u$ is monotonically decreasing in $(0$, $+\infty)$. Therefore, $\log _{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x^{2}-2 x-3\right)$ is monotonically increasing in $(-\infty,-1)$.
informal_statement:
2. (2002 National High School Competition Question) The monotonic increasing interval of the function $f(x)=\log _{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x^{2}-2 x-3\right)$ is ( ).
A. $(-\infty,-1)$
B. $(-\infty, 1)$
C. $(1,+\infty)$
D. $(3,+\infty)$
